headline: 'I don't believe this b*****ks about Man Utd star Marcus Rashford – it'll never happen'
body: Former Liverpool and Man United star Michael Owen doesn't think that Marcus Rashford will leave Old Trafford insisting he doesn't believe any talk of the forward moving on
Michael Owen says he doesn't believe the 'b*****ks' surrounding the future of Manchester United striker Marcus Rashford.

Rashford underwent a difficult season with United and has been linked with a move away from Old Trafford after failing to make the squad for Euro 2024, with fans and pundits speculating that he could seek to reignite his career at a new club. However, former Red Devil Owen isn't entertaining any of the hearsay and firmly believes Rashford will be lining up at United next season.

‌Owen, speaking to BoyleSports, who will offer early payout on EURO 2024 matches this summer, said: "Rashford won't go, I'm sure of it, he's Manchester through and through. The whole club is a struggle, but he has it in his locker." The ex-Real Madrid goal-scorer conceded that there was a chance Rashford could end up playing his football elsewhere but is not convinced all the elements come together for any club to take a punt on the 26-year-old."He might leave but his value is so high, who would pay it?" Owen said, "They might be thinking, is his attitude right? Is he in great form? I don't see how it can all come together at the moment." Owen even hinted that PSG could take advantage of Rashford's uncertain situation at United and swoop for the striker but admitted he just can't see it happening and preferred to put it down to the rumour mill.

"There was talk of PSG but I can't see that. Who can afford him? And would Man Utd want him to go, particularly with a new manager?" Owen said, "I just don't believe all this b*****ks that goes round all the time at this part of the year, it never happens."

Rashford was in and out of the United squad as the club endured its worst English top-flight season in 30 years and as a result of his form, Gareth Southgate handed out the crushing blow of excluding him from his 33-man preliminary squad ahead of the Three Lions' European Championships campaign in Germany. Rashford's future could perhaps be in further doubt after the announcement that United are to keep faith with under-fire manager Erik ten Hag for next season.

However, any doubt of where Rashford, allegiances lie was put to bed after he uploaded a picture of himself in floods of tears after Manchester United won the FA Cup. in May The photo posted on Instagram also included the caption: 'That's what the club means to me'.

Owen addressed the sensational headlines that can plague this time of the football calendar and how constant talk can often come to nothing. Making parallels with Rashford's situation, Owen referenced how the build-up to big tournaments is often soured with negative press that rarely comes true.

Owen said: "This time of year is hilarious. Two or three months before every World Cup there is this big crisis everyone talks about. When the World Cup was in South America there were these killer mosquitos that were going to kill everyone, then one of the next ones was the stadiums not getting built and so on. Then lo and behold they are brilliant World Cups."

"Football is the same, with about five or six games to go, all the teams doing poorly get numerous articles of big clearouts. They say it every single year and the reality is two players go and you have barely heard of them."

headline: IShowSpeed's wild life – fireworks in bedroom, e-dating scandals, Cristiano Ronaldo obsession
body: YouTuber IShowSpeed, known for his love of Cristiano Ronaldo and Manchester United, has faced plenty of controversial moments since becoming an online star and rapper
Internet sensation IShowSpeed has been swarmed by SWAT teams and set off fireworks in his bedroom during his controversial rise to success.

IShowSpeed, real name Darren Jason Watkins Jr, came to wider prominence among football fans due to his obsession with Cristiano Ronaldo. The 19-year-old infamously featured on Sky Sports in November 2022 as he attempted to meet his idol.

Sky Sports deleted traces of IShowSpeed’s segment after historical misogynistic comments emerged but this did not slow his success. Watkins subsequently revealed getting a tattoo of the forward, as well as dedicating a song to the former Manchester United hero.

The United fan boasts a combined 52 million subscribers across YouTube and TikTok, having initially gone viral for his live streams on Twitch. Here is a closer look at the YouTuber’s rise to fame and most controversial moments.
Who is IShowSpeed?

IShowSpeed created his first YouTube channel in 2016 but it was not until 2020 that he began to earn a number of subscribers. Clips of his streams began circulating on TikTok and Speed reached one million subscribers in June 2021, with his audience growing at an astonishing rate.

He moved to Los Angeles with fellow streamer Adin Ross and released his first rap single in 2021. In the last year, Watkins has fought KSI in a charity boxing sparring match. The internet personality also featured at Wrestlemania 40 in April, appearing in a Prime bottle costume during Logan Paul’s match with Kevin Owens and WWE legend Randy Orton.
Fireworks, SWAT team and other controversies

He once marked US Independence Day by setting off a Pikachu firework in his bedroom. Believing it to be a firecracker, Speed was surprised when the Pokemon began firing multiple fireworks and shouted to his mother for help during a live stream. The fire service was called, though Watkins repeated the stunt the following year.

Watkins’ live streams have also seen the YouTuber interrupted by SWAT teams because of hoax calls to law enforcement by trolls. After receiving false information, armed police have twice shown up to Watkins’ address in an attempt to apprehend IShowSpeed.

In August 2023, Speed accidentally flashed his penis to 25k viewers as a result of a jumpscare. The clip went viral on social media but the accidental nature meant that YouTube opted against taking further action.
The Three Lions are among the favourites to win this summer's Euro 2024 tournament and you can get your hands on the brand new Nike home and away kits before the first whistle.
Cristiano Ronaldo obsession

Watkins was already a star before his adoration of Ronaldo became a notable part of his online persona. Having travelled to Old Trafford, Craven Cottage and the Qatar World Cup, it was not until June 2023 that IShowSpeed finally met Ronaldo after a 3-0 win for Portugal over Bosnia and Herzegovina.

A year earlier, Speed had released a song titled, ‘Ronaldo (Sewey)’, as well as a single in honour of the last World Cup, both of which commanded millions of views on YouTube. In January 2023, the influencer revealed a tattoo portrait of Ronaldo on his arm.

Despite his idol leaving United, Watkins has remained a fan of the Red Devils and live-streamed himself at Wembley during their recent FA Cup triumph. He has also made a name for himself in charity football matches, notably whipping referee Mark Clattenburg with his shirt after seeing a goal disallowed for offside and putting in a controversial slide tackle on former AC Milan and Real Madrid star Kaka.
E-dating scandal and misogynistic comments

In December 2021, IShowSpeed participated in a livestream e-dating show. Watkins was the first player to be eliminated after making threatening comments to a female participant, later rejoining the stream to fire further slurs at the contestant. The incident led IShowSpeed to be banned from Twitch for "sexual coercion or intimidation". His ban was reportedly revoked last year.

A few months later, a Twitch clip of Watkins resurfaced, telling a female gamer to “Get off the f****** game and do your husband's dishes." This led him to be banned from playing Valorant and all other Riot Games titles. IShowSpeed apologised for his comments and claimed that he had received racist comments from other players that day, suggesting that this had contributed towards his behaviour.

headline: Man Utd flop tops list of players whose transfer values have plummeted most in 2023/24
body: All it takes is one bad season for a player's transfer value to significantly decrease, as evidenced by the top 10 biggest price tag decreases over the last year
Manchester United winger Antony is joint-top of a list of players with the greatest transfer value decreases last season.

The 24-year-old endured a difficult 2023/24 campaign, registering only five goal contributions across his 38 appearances in all competitions. He's also got the weight of the £86million fee United paid for him hanging over his head.

They look unlikely to recoup anywhere near that sum if they decide to sell him this summer, with Transfermarkt now estimating him to be worth €25million (£21m). That's a drop of €35m (£29.5m) from July 2023.

And it's only matched by France forward Randal Kolo Muani, who joined PSG from Eintracht Frankfurt in a €90m (£76m) transfer last summer. His proposed market value has fallen from €80m (£67m) to €45m (£38m).

In third place is Neymar, who made a €90m (£76m) move of his own to the Saudi Pro League's Al-Hilal. That was an overpayment compared to the €60m (£50.5m) he was estimated to be worth - which has now halved.
An ACL injury which has ruled the 32-year-old out of action since October will have contributed to that. Wesley Fofana of Chelsea has been sidelined for a whole year with the same problem.

As a result, his valuation has also dropped by €30m (£25m) to €25m (£21m). Tottenham's Pierre-Emile Hojbjerg follows in fifth, seeing his price tag drop by €27m (£23m) from €45m (£38m) to €18m (£15m).

That will be mainly because his contract in north London is approaching its final year. There's a four-way tie in sixth place between Joshua Kimmich, Reece James, Mason Mount and Joao Cancelo, all with €25m (£21m) decreases.

Kimmich has gone from €75m (£63m) to €50m (£42m), as like Hojbjerg his deal with Bayern Munich expires in 2025. James' repeated injury woes, which kept him in the treatment room for much of the season again, mean he's fallen from €65m (£55m) to €40m (£34m).

Mount, who United surprisingly paid £60m to Chelsea for last summer, has dropped from the €60m (£50.5m) mark to €35m (£29.5m) after his own injury-hit season. And Cancelo, who was on loan at Barcelona from Manchester City, saw his halve from €50m (£42m).

Rounding out the top 10 of the greatest decreases is Marco Verratti, who after joining Qatari side Al-Arabi from PSG in September in a €45m (£38m) move has seen his €40m (£34m) estimation also cut in half.

headline: David Beckham's net worth compared to his Manchester United Class of '92 teammates
body: David Beckham has amassed a fortune since bursting onto the scene with Manchester United as part of the famed Class of '92, but how does his wealth compare to his former teammates?
David Beckham has made millions throughout his career thanks to his business savvy moves both on and off the football pitch.

Undeniably one of the most talented players of his era, the ex-England captain's career highlights include legendary moments such as his 1996 goal against Wimbledon and his two injury-time assists in the 1999 Champions League final.

But in addition to his time playing for the likes of his boyhood club Manchester United, Real Madrid and L.A Galaxy, David quickly created Brand Beckham with the help of his popstar wife Victoria Beckham.

His high-profile relationship off the pitch and his exceptional performance on it made him one of the most marketable sports stars globally. Early partnerships with Brylcreem and adidas were just the start of his burgeoning business portfolio, with the release of his Netflix series last year documenting his journey towards becoming the first modern celebrity footballer.

David's eye watering wealth, thanks to his lucrative playing career, savvy business ventures during and post-career, and his current involvement with the Herons, is estimated to be around £372million ($450m). Alongside his wife Victoria, he boasts a portfolio of properties worldwide, including a Miami penthouse valued at £22.6m and a London townhouse worth £30m.

Despite reaching the pinnacle of his career, it's evident that he hasn't forgotten his humble beginnings as a trainee at Old Trafford. His bond with his former Red Devils teammates is demonstrated through his co-ownership of Salford City alongside them. However, he isn't the only member of the legendary Class of '92 - the six footballers who rose from Manchester United's academy to become global stars - to have accumulated a fortune. Below, we examine the net worth of 'Fergie's Fledglings', three decades after they first made their mark...

Over the past decade, Gary Neville has emerged as one of the leading pundits on TV, with his prominent role alongside old rival Jamie Carragher on Sky Sports introducing him to new audiences. Since retiring in 2011, he has also immersed himself in his diverse business interests.

Beckham's former right-wing partner is one of Manchester's most prominent advocates, consistently investing in the city over the years. He has held property in the North West city since he was 21 and launched his 'Relentless' business empire in 2015.

Now, he's estimated to be worth a cool £20 million, with his business success spanning ventures like Salford City and GG Hospitality, which constructed Hotel Football in Manchester. He also kick-started the UA92 University alongside his Class of '92 mates and even appeared in the latest series of BBC business show Dragon's Den.

The younger of the renowned Neville brothers, Phil, has dived into a variety of interests after retiring his football boots in 2013. The Bury-born star has primarily pursued coaching, with tenures as the manager of the England Women's team and at Beckham's Inter Miami.

Currently, he serves as the assistant coach for the Canadian men's national team after being let go by his old teammate earlier this season. He also holds business stakes at Salford City, with his coaching salary since his playing days contributing to his estimated £20 million fortune.

The former England and Manchester United midfielder joined his ex-teammates in investing in Salford City back in 2014 and he remains involved at the club to this day. Butt has had a varied life following his retirement and his business ventures have included investments in gaming and blockchain company Gaimin.

The former Old Trafford star has also has some experience as a coach following his playing days and he served as Manchester United U23 interim coach in 2016-17. He went on to become head of first team development in 2019 before stepping down in 2021. As a result, of his estimated net worth stands at approximately £15m.

The former United midfield maestro has juggled his involvement with Salford City as an owner, with two stints as the club's caretaker manager in 2015 and 2020. In between these short spells in the dugout at Moor Lane, he has also served as manager at hometown club Oldham Athletic in 2019. From a business point of view, he has also invested in the Scholes Gym in Oldham, which has saw him sink £500,000 into its coffers. The former England star is said to be worth an estimated £20 million.

The former PFA Player of the Year had the longest career out of his Class of '92 co-stars, hanging up his boots after 24 incredible seasons at United. Following retirement, the Welshman has had a varied coaching career, including a brief stint as caretaker manager at Old Trafford in 2014.

On from this, he remained part of the inner sanctum at United, serving as assistant manager to Louis van Gaal until 2016. He would then be handed the opportunity to manage his country in 2018, a role he would fulfil for the next four years. As a result of his business ventures, which include GG Hospitality, alongside Gary Neville, and Salford City, as well as his lucrative playing and coaching career, he is estimated to be worth £50 million.

headline: LiveTransfer news LIVE: Arsenal told Onana price tag, Man Utd's bid Branthwaite rejected, Chelea face Olise issue
body: Arsenal have contacted Everton about the possibility of signing midfield ace Amadou Onana, a move which could derail Manchester United's pursuit of team-mate Jarrad Branthwaite
The 2024 summer transfer window is less than two days old - but it's already kicking into gear.

Manchester United have lodged their first bid to buy top target Jarrad Branthwaite, although their offer of just £35million up front has been scoffed at by Everton. After agreeing personal terms with the 21-year-old defender, United hope to capitalise on Everton's well-documented financial woes, but a move from rivals Arsenal could dramatically change the landscape and put the Toffees in a much stronger bargaining position.

That's because Arsenal have made contact to sign Branthwaite's team-mate, Amadou Onana, with the Gunners told to pay at least £50m. Should that deal be completed by June 30, that'd likely be enough for Everton to avoid any further sanctions from the Premier League and hold out even longer to try and keep hold of Branthwaite.

It's less straightforward for Crystal Palace, however, as star man Michael Olise has a release clause worth around £60million. Mirror Football understands that Chelsea have already made contact with Palace but aren't eligible to trigger that clause directly because they didn't qualify for the Champions League.
Stay tuned throughout Saturday as we bring you the latest transfer news from the Premier League and beyond.

Arsenal have contacted Everton to register their interest in Amadou Onana - and have been told to pay at least £50million.
Onana, 22, has established himself as one of the Premier League's most promising defensive midfielders after his club-record move from Lille two years ago.

The Belgium international has repeatedly been linked with a move to Arsenal and after the Gunners made a formal enquiry, the Liverpool ECHO report that Everton have set their asking price at a minimum of £50m.

Former United forward Teddy Sheringham believes the club need another forward. Perhaps no surprise given he was in a squad with Cole, Yorke and Solskjaer.

Sheringham told TG Casino: “I think Rasmus Hojlund has done alright. It’s tough playing centre-forward these days because wingers don’t really get down to the by-line and feed players in the box, and he’s not getting an awful lot of supply in midfield. I think he’s feeding off scraps at Manchester United at the moment, but he’s fought well and looks quite strong. It’s a difficult position to play at the club as such a young lad and I think he’s done okay.

“Having said that, the club need another striker without a doubt. They’re going to be playing a lot of games next season and encountering a lot of injuries, so they’ll definitely need another striker from somewhere.”
While the transfer window opened today, there's also the small matter of Euro 2024 getting underway in little over an hour. Take a look at the Germany side below:
Neuer, Kimmich, Rudiger, Tah, Mittelstadt, Andrich, Kroos, Musiala, Gündogan, Wirtz, Havertz.

Stuttgart forward Serhou Guirassy enjoyed an impressive year in the Bundesliga and is as a result is expected to draw plenty of interest in the coming weeks and months after netting 30 goals in 30 games.

Manchester United have been linked with the striker who has been touted to have a bargain release clause of £17m. While no move is close yet, it doesn't sound like the sharpshooter expects to wait long for a deal.
He told Sky Germany: “Nothing is advanced, I’m still under contract with VfB [Stuttgart]. Now it’s time for a vacation. We’ll know in a few weeks what will happen."
Netherlands and Bayer Leverkusen star Jeremie Frimpong isn't giving too much credence to speculation over his future just yet.
The Dutch wing-back has been linked with Barcelona, Manchester United and Liverpool already this summer and is reported to be available for £34m.
He told ESPN: "It’s just rumours.. I don't read rumours! Rumours are just rumours, anyone can say anything."
Adam Lallana has returned to Southampton on a one-year deal after 10 years away from the club.
Lallana said: "Although it sounds like a bit of a fairytale, in my head there’s still a job to do and I’m really confident I’ve still got a lot to give to this football club.”
Reports suggest Spurs have rejected a bid from AC Milan for defender Emerson Royal.

The Brazilian is said to be a key target for the Italian side and the Lilywhites will be open to do a deal. The Serie A giants arrived with an offer of £17m but that does not appear enough for Daniel Levy, after Spurs signed the defender for nearer £30m in 2021.
There remains hope a deal could be reached for a fee of £21m.

It has been reported that Chelsea and Spurs are among the clubs that could activate Dominic Solanke's Bournemouth release clause should they wish. The former Blues and Liverpool forward would still require a suitor to be willing to pay his £65m fee however.

The two clubs, who are said to be interested in landing a forward in the coming months, could yet face competition in Liverpool, Arsenal, Man City and Manchester United, who it is claimed can also utilise the release clause.
The Gunners could say goodbyee to Reiss Nelson this summer with reports suggesting the winger has told the club he would like to assess his options for a transfer.
The north London side turned down deals in January and would want in the region of £20m. Crystal Palace, Fulham, Nottingham Forest and West Ham could prove interested.

The Red Devils have made their opening offer to sign Everton's Jarrad Branthwaite, according to the Athletic. The bid is said to be in the region of £35m. The Toffees are set to reject the offer and deem it 'unaccaptable'.
The Serie A side have made progress in their bid to land goalkeeper Josep Martínez. Fabrizio Romano reports that personal terms have been agreed for the Genoa goalkeeper.
The transfer guru claims that talks are at an advanced stages between the teams. Inter's opening proposal is said to be €10m plus one player.
Borussia Dortmund have wasted no time appointing a new manager following yesterday's exit of Edin Terzic.
The German side have revealed that ex-Liverpool and Real Madrid midfielder Nuri Sahin has been promoted having both played and coached the side previously.
A statement read: "Borussia Dortmund confirms Nuri Şahin as new Head Coach. The former BVB player himself joined the coaching staff earlier this year and will now lead the team through June 2027."
Well, this is one we didn't see coming, Virgil van Dijk could be leaving Liverpool.

According to Marca, the Dutch defender has recevied a huge offer to join Saudi side Al-Nassr. They are reportedly so keen to sign him that they are willing to make him the highest-paid defender in the world.
Talks are already said to have taken place. Van Dijk's current Liverpool deal expires next summer.
Arsenal goalkeeper Aaron Ramsdale has indicated he "never" wants to go another year playing as little as he did in the 2023-24 campaign.

Ramsdale, who is part of England's squad for Euro 2024, began the last season as the Gunners' first choice. However, after losing his spot to summer signing David Raya, he ended the campaign with just a handful of league outings.
The 26-year-old has been linked with a summer exit as he aims to secure first team football. Nothing is set in stone, though, and he said reports of a Newcastle switch were news to him.
"No footballer wants to not play," Ramsdale told talkSPORT in the lead-up to England's Euros opener. "I’ve had a tough year personally not playing and I never want to do that again."
Aston Villa will tear up Philippe Coutinho's contract to allow him to rejoin Vasco da Gama, it has been claimed.

Coutinho joined Villa from Barcelona in 2022 but found opportunities hard to come by after Steven Gerrard - the manager who brought him to Villa Park - was dismissed. He spent last season on loan at Qatari club Al-Duhail but now looks set for a permanent exit.

The Brazil international was once one of the most expensive players in world football when he left Liverpool for Barcelona in 2018. That £142million move was far from a success, though, with Barca taking a significant hit when selling him on four years later.
Now, things appear to be going full circle. Coutinho began his career with Vasco before moving to Europe as a teenager and now looks set to return to the Rio de Janeiro club.

headline: Man Utd transfer news: Barcelona eye Kobbie Mainoo as first summer deal 'agreed'
body: Manchester United now know who is going to be in charge for the forthcoming season and work can now get underway on the Red Devils’ transfer business with the window finally open
The 2024 transfer window is finally open - and Manchester United look set to start with a bang.
Sir Jim Ratcliffe has already promised significant investment into the Red Devils’ current playing squad. That will certainly excite current manager Erik ten Hag.
The Dutchman’s future was previously up in the air but he has been told that he will be staying. He could also sign a new deal at Old Trafford.
On the topic of signing on the dotted line, some players could be doing that to become Man United players in the near future. Get up to date with all of the latest transfer news and rumours:
Man United academy graduate Kobbie Mainoo was one of the Red Devils’ breakout stars at Old Trafford last season. But he might not be at the club for very long.
According to reports in Belgium, Spanish giants Barcelona are interested in moving for the young midfielder. The Red Devils, however, are also trying to do all they can to keep him.

It is suggested that Man United officials are aware of Barca’s interest and have opened talks regarding a new deal. Mainoo’s representatives are asking for an extension to his current deal with a significant wage increase. The 19-year-old has three years left on his deal at Old Trafford.
While Mainoo could potentially be on his way out, one man who could be arriving is Jarrad Branthwaite. The Red Devils are long-term admirers of the Everton defender.
And it appears that a deal could be close. According to The Times, Man United have agreed personal terms with the England centre-back regarding a move.
It is reported that the Red Devils would be willing to pay him between £150,000 and £160,000 per week. However, there now remains the hurdle of agreeing a deal with Everton.
The Toffees reportedly want to receive around £70million for their star defender. In case of failing to agree a move, the Red Devils have alternatives…
Who should Man Utd sign in the summer? Share your suggestions in the comments below
Should they fail to sign Branthwaite, Man United have been handed a boost if they move for Lenny Yoro. The Lille star features on the Red Devils’ defensive shortlist.

According to Mundo Deportivo, Real Madrid are also interested but will not pay the fee that Lille are demanding. It is reported that the French side want to bank €60million (£50.6million) for the 18-year-old.
Paris Saint-Germain are also interested in the youngster. Yoro’s deal with Lille expires next summer so the club could be forced into lowering their demands.

headline: Man Utd to make with improved Jarrad Branthwaite bid after Everton's firm response
body: Manchester United hope to sign Jarrad Branthwaite but Everton do not plan to allow the Red Devils to complete a transfer cheaply for the young, Goodison Park defender
Manchester United are expected to make a second offer for Everton defender Jarrad Branthwaite after seeing their opening bid firmly rejected.

Erik ten Hag's side are set to present improved terms after their first offer of £34million plus £8m in add-ons did not tempt the Toffees, per Mail Online. The proposal was deemed 'unacceptable' by the Merseyside club.

Everton are said to value the 21-year-old, who narrowly missed out on England's Euro 2024 squad, closer to a figure of £75m and are reluctant to sanction a sale for a player they would like to keep. The youngster thrived under Sean Dyche and completed 41 appearances amidst a chaotic backdrop which saw Everton deducted points.

The club, who have seen Roma owner Dan Friedkin come to an agreement with owner Farhad Moshiri for his stake, have endured financial difficulties over the last 12 months. Everton do no intend to let those issues result in a cut-price deal for Branthwaite however.
The club are not entertaining a fire-sale and, amid the suggestion that United had agreed personal terms with Branthwaite, are adamant their Premier League rivals will not take advantage of them.

The Red Devils £80m purchase of Harry Maguire in 2019, when he became the world's most expensive defender has set an unwanted benchmark for Sir Jim Ratcliffe's team. Everton would also look to highlight the lavish fees spent by Man City and Chelsea on Josko Gvardiol, £78m, and Wesley Fofana, £70m in recent years.

Branthwaite's contract runs until 2027, leaving Everton with a strong bargaining position. United will need to decide how much cash they are willing to part with after suffering from defensive injuries last term and Raphael Varane having left he club.

The 13-times Premier League champions could yet see a dramatic overhaul of their squad with a 12-man clear-out touted before the season had finished. In addition to Branthwaite United have eyed Bayer Leverkusen's defensive duo Edmond Tapsoba and Jeremie Frimpong, Wolves midfielder Joao Gomes and his teammate Pedro Neto, and Borussia Dortmund forward Donyell Malen.

headline: Man Utd star 'questioned Erik ten Hag's approach' before quitting the club
body: Erik ten Hag faced an uncertain future before being given Sir Jim Ratcliffe’s faith ahead of next season but some of his current stars had plenty of doubt about the Dutchman
Raphael Varane and Casemiro were ‘dissenting voices’ opposing Erik ten Hag ’s methods at Manchester United before Sir Jim Ratcliffe decided to stick with the manager.
The Dutchman faced an uncertain future at the club following a dire second campaign at Old Trafford. But Ratcliffe has opted to stick with Ten Hag following a post-season review.
He is now in talks regarding a new contract with the Red Devils. However, that decision might not go down well with a couple of Man United stars.

According to The Athletic, former Real Madrid duo Varane and Casemiro were not particularly convinced by Ten Hag’s ethos. It is reported that the pair spoke to teammates about the methods employed by Carlo Ancelotti and Zinedine Zidane in Spain.

They claimed that they were given more freedom and ‘workload agency’ with Real Madrid, while Ten Hag’s positional style was not appreciated. The pair were told that Man United were a completely different club to the Spanish champions.

LaLiga was also labelled as a slower-paced competition with less strength in depth so the same methods would not translate. Despite that, both Casemiro and Varane remained vocal and at times ‘dissenting voices’.

The news comes after Ten Hag was forced deny a rift with the French centre-back last season. Speaking in November, he said: "Rapha Varane? I don't know what you're talking about. It's rumours. Very important player, but there's internal competition and there should be at a top club, as we are."
Who should Man United sign this summer? Share your suggestions in the comments below

Since then, it has been confirmed that Varane is due to leave Old Trafford at the end of his contract. He penned an emotional farewell to the club ahead of making his final Red Devils appearance in the FA Cup final.

"To you guys, supporters of Manchester United, it's been an amazing few years to play for this special club and wear that shirt," Varane said. "The first time I went to Old Trafford as a Man United player was insane, the atmosphere was amazing.
"I fell in love with the club, with the fans. You have to play for Man United to understand what that represents. For my kids, it's home here. It's going to be a special place for me, for life.
"When the fans went to Wembley [last season], it's something they will remember for life. To share that moment with them was absolutely amazing.
"Despite the fact we had a difficult season, I'm very positive for the future. The new owners are coming with a clear plan and a great strategy.
"I'll see you at Old Trafford to say goodbye for the last game at home this season and it's going to be very emotional day for me, for sure."

headline: Scotland and Man Utd icon who starred at the Euros looks unrecognisable with huge beard
body: Former Scotland star Brian McClair was a goal-machine for Celtic and Man Utd - but many would struggle to recognise the four-time Premier League winning striker
Manchester United and Scotland legend Brian McClair is barely recognisable following his remarkable transformation.

The former striker was a staple in the Scotland national team from 1986 to 1993. He is best known for his time at Celtic and United, where he made an immediate impact and graced the Old Trafford pitch for 11 years.

Now aged 60, McClair looks completely different to the player who scored an impressive 31 goals in his first season with the Red Devils. The Lanarkshire-born star was spotted in 2023 enjoying a pint in a Manchester pub named The Gold Cup.
He sported a large white beard and long grey hair – a far cry from his clean-shaven look and brown locks during his playing days.

McClair remains involved in the world of football these days, hosting his podcast 'Life With Brian', where he's welcomed guests such as journalist Geoff Shreeves, presenter Mark Pougatch and cricket legend David 'Bumble' Lloyd.

In his prime, McClair was one of the top players in both the Scottish and English top flight, scoring a staggering 126 goals in 204 appearances for Celtic. His prolific goal-scoring record continued at United under Sir Alex Ferguson, where he became the first player since George Best in the 1967/68 season to score over 20 league goals.
His successful stint with the club saw him win four Premier League titles, two FA Cups and the League Cup.
McClair also earned 30 caps for Scotland between 1986 and 1993. He made his debut in a 3-0 Euro 1988 qualifier over Luxembourg at Hampden Park in November 1986.

Despite Scotland's failure to qualify for that edition of the Euros, McClair became a regular fixture in the team, helping the Tartan Army secure a place in the 1990 World Cup. However, he was left out of the final tournament squad by manager Andy Roxburgh.

He finally had the opportunity to represent his country on the big stage at the 1992 European Championships, where he scored in a 3-0 win over the CIS (formerly USSR), following losses to Germany and the Netherlands. He hung up his boots at Motherwell in 1998.

headline: Erik ten Hag 'tore into Antony' in dressing room after Man Utd star disobeyed him
body: Antony has failed to live up to expectations since making a big money move to Manchester United and Red Devils boss Erik ten Hag is said to have laid into the winger on at least two occasions last season
Manchester United manager Erik ten Hag 'ripped into' Antony at times last season after the winger disobeyed him.

United forked out around £86million to sign Antony in 2022, with the Brazil international reunited with Ten Hag after the pair worked together at Ajax. However, Antony has failed to live up to expectations so far, with just 16 goal contributions in 82 games.

He also publicly disobeyed his manager twice during games last season, making a 'mind blown' gesture after being asked to fill in at left-back during United's dramatic 4-3 win over Liverpool in the FA Cup.

Antony also made the same gesture when Ten Hag asked him to play there in the 1-0 loss to Arsenal two months later and, according to the Athletic, the Dutchman responded by laying into him after the game.

The report states that he 'ripped into the Brazilian, telling him bluntly he had to play where he was told'. Ten Hag is also said to have brutally criticised Antony after a poor performance off the bench in their 2-0 win over Everton.
It is claimed that Antony 'appeared visibly affected' as a result of Ten Hag's comments, with the manager said to be 'deeply disappointed' with the winger's performances since he joined the club.
Publicly, however, Ten Hag has repeatedly defended Antony and stated in February that he is "unstoppable" when he is at his best. "With Antony, I backed him for a long time," he told reporters.

"I know his abilities, great abilities, I know from the past he is unstoppable, no defender can stop him because he's one of the quickest in the first 10 yards. When he plays that game I'm sure he will perform.
"He's resilient, he's a character and he will fight back. I back him and he now has to wait for his chance and, once he is there, he has to pick up."

headline: Harry Maguire recovering from England Euros heartache in £6,400-a-night Turkish resort
body: England and Manchester United defender Harry Maguire will play no part in his country's European Championships campaign and made clear his frustrations after missing out
As England's players prepare for their Euro 2024 opener against Serbia, Harry Maguire has been in Turkey at the five-star Maxx Royal Belek resort.

Manchester United centre-back Maguire lost his battle to make the squad after an injury-hit club season. He was named in Gareth Southgate's 33-man preliminary group, but there was no place for him in the final 26 who have travelled to Germany.

Maguire featured in every England game in each of the last two World Cups and played five times at Euro 2020 after missing the start of the tournament through injury. He missed the last month of the domestic season, though, and has not recovered in time to play a part.

He has jetted off for Antalya, on Turkey's Mediterranean coast, to wind down at the luxury resort, which sets guests back a pretty penny. A week's stay in the Maxx Royal Belek's deluxe accommodation costs up to £6,400 per night, though cheaper suites can become available for less than £1,000.

Maxx Royal Belek offers guests a range of different types of accommodation, from individual suites to detached villas on the premises. Villas include a private pool and terrace, while there's also a golf course and a range of restaurants with Michelin-starred chef Alfredo Russo offering a fine dining option.

Maguire has been pictured winding down at the resort. He was snapped on a sun lounger and pictured drinking a beer by the pool, while one source told The Mail the former Leicester City defender appeared relaxed while spending time with family at the resort,

With Maguire failing to recover from injury, England's centre-back options are limited for their Euros opener against Serbia. John Stones and Marc Guehi started the final warm-up game against Iceland, though Stones has been ill in the days since.

"I am devastated not to have been selected to play for England at the Euros this summer," Maguire said after his absence was confirmed. "Despite my best efforts, I have not been able to overcome an injury to my calf. Maybe I pushed myself too hard, to try and make it.

"Simply, I am absolutely gutted. For me, representing England is the highest honour. It means everything to me. If I can’t help the team as a player, I will support them as a fan – along with the rest of the country. Go and win it boys. Next, I will return to the supervision of the Manchester United medical team in order to prepare for next season."

Harry Kane and Declan Rice were among the England players to reach out to Maguire in the light of the setback. The 31-year-old hasn't missed a competitive England game of any kind since 2021, when he sat out a pair of World Cup qualifiers, while the last game he missed in a tournament proper was the goalless draw with Scotland at Euro 2020.

“Harry Maguire’s consistently been one of our main first contact from set-plays but we have got other options within that, but we have got other opportunities to be creative in our set-plays as well," manager Southgate said, addressing a potential issue in Germany. "But some smaller players can cope really well and mark really well. You saw Kobbie Mainoo doing a pretty good job from corners for Manchester United in the FA Cup final for example."
England begin their Euro 2024 campaign against Serbia in Gelsenkirchen on Sunday evening. Their second group game is against Denmark, with their third against Slovenia.

headline: Everton respond to claims Man Utd have agreed transfer terms with Jarrad Branthwaite
body: Everton have responded after claims Manchester United have agreed personal terms with England centre-back Jarrad Branthwaite over a big-money transfer to Old Trafford
Everton are adamant Manchester United will not sign Jarrad Branthwaite in a cut-price deal after claims they have agreed terms with the England defender.

It is understood Everton have not received any contact from United for Branthwaite, who they value at £75million. United think they can capitalise on Everton’s money troubles because of their drawn-out takeover to land Branthwaite for just £40million.
It is understood the Blues want around twice that amount for the 21-year-old centre-half, who just missed out on Euro 2024 after winning his first cap under Gareth Southgate.
United made Harry Maguire the world ’s most expensive defender when they paid Leicester £80million for him in 2019 and Everton value Branthwaite in that region.

The Blues can also point to Josko Gvardiol and Manchester City paid RB Leipzig £77.6million for the defender a year ago, while Chelsea splashed out £70million to land Wesley Fofana from Leicester in 2022.

Everton’s director of football Kevin Thelwell admits some players may be sold because of the uncertainty in the boardroom and owner Farhad Moshiri is speaking to different groups after 777 Partners’ exclusivity agreement ended last month. However, the Blues are adamant this does not mean there will be a fire sale at Goodison Park.

Thelwell and manager Sean Dyche are getting on with business and skipper Seamus Coleman has agreed a new deal to bring up 16 seasons with the Blues and the club’s last at Goodison. The Republic of Ireland defender holds the Everton record for most Premier League appearances with 364 and has been Blues captain since 2019.

“Everyone knows what Everton means to me, and I’m very proud and honoured to sign a new contract and to keep playing for this special club in the best league in the world,” said Coleman, 35. "I give it my all for the football club and I’m just really happy to extend my time here. I’m going to cherish and enjoy every moment.
Your turn! Should Jarrad Branthwaite sign for Man United  ? Join the debate in the comments section

“It’s hard to believe it’s going to be our last season at Goodison, such a special place to me and every Evertonian. Of course, I want to be part of that. I still feel I can do a job for this football club on and off the pitch. This being our last season at Goodison is a nice way to go into the campaign but I wouldn’t have signed the contract if I didn’t feel capable of contributing to the team.

“I’ve just played two matches for my country. I feel good and I want to help the lads on the pitch. I’m still enjoying it so what better place to do that than at the Club you love? I think the manager steadied that ship massively last season with our performances. I just want to be part of that and to continue to be a part of this football club.”

headline: How Man Utd can line up next season in dream scenario as Erik ten Hag told transfer budget
body: Manchester United decided to stick with Erik ten Hag after much deliberation but have stripped down the Dutchman's influence on recruitment for the summer transfer window
Manchester United have started the summer transfer window with a limited budget of £50million, meaning that Erik ten Hag and co. will need to do some wheeling and dealing.

Ten Hag has been given the go-ahead to continue as United manager after club chiefs including co-owner Sir Jim Ratcliffe spent two-and-a-half weeks deliberating over his future. Ratcliffe and other senior executives even met with multiple candidates to replace the Dutchman, although settled on giving Ten Hag the start of next season to prove himself.

Now the Red Devils can focus on recruitment, with plenty of ins and outs expected before transfer deadline day on August 30. Sales will be key in funding new signings, with only young trio Kobbie Mainoo, Alejandro Garnacho and Rasmus Hojlund deemed untouchable from United's current squad.

For Casemiro, Jadon Sancho and Mason Greenwood, however, it's a different story. Casemiro is being courted by Saudi Arabian side Al-Nassr, who if last summer is anything to go by would be willing to give United a healthy sum of cash.

Meanwhile, Greenwood is almost certain to leave Old Trafford either permanently or via another loan after spending the 2023-24 season with Getafe. Italian giants Juventus have shown interest and reportedly submitted a £40million bid this week.

Sancho would likely command a similar fee, as Borussia Dortmund - who he spent the second half of last term on loan with - are keen to sign him on a permanent basis. Dortmund don't have cash to burn but know that Sancho and Ten Hag's broken relationship puts them in a strong bargaining position.
Peripheral members of Ten Hag's squad such as Victor Lindelof, Christian Eriksen and Donny van de Beek, are also on the chopping block, each with 12 months left on their respective contracts.

The transfer window officially opened on Friday morning, hours after it emerged that United had agreed personal terms with the representatives of top target Jarrad Branthwaite. A fee still needs to be agreed with Everton, who'll only consider selling Branthwaite if they receive a 'mega offer'.

Should United sign the 21-year-old, he'd likely slot in at centre-back next to Lisandro Martinez. Branthwaite is predominately left-footed but has shown to be comfortable on his right, meaning that the Everton star would work as a replacement for now-free agent Raphael Varane.
Your turn! Who should Manchester United sign this summer? Let us know your picks in the comments section

What'll be crucial to the defence's success is how United line up in midfield. Fulham linchpin Palhinha and Benfica wonderkid Joao Neves have both been linked, although would cost £60m and £84m respectively, according to reports.

A cheaper option is Monaco's Youssouf Fofana, who the Red Devils have been tipped to sign alongside Arsenal and West Ham. Fofana, 25, has entered the final year of his contract in the French Riviera, where Ratcliffe notably lives.

The midfielder dynamo has been included in France's squad for Euro 2024, which could give him an extra opportunity to impress potentially suitors like United. It's even been claimed that Monaco would be willing to sell him for just £20m - and the player himself is ready to depart.
"I have spoken about it with the hierarchy, it isn't a secret," Fofana recently confirmed. "We had exchanges and they agreed to accompany me in this new stage.

"If [a move] doesn't happen, I still have a year left and I will be happy to stay. We were in agreement that we would accompany each other in this process in which everyone should be a winner, be it me or the club."

Staying with the French, Michael Olise is on United's wish-list amid hot competition from Chelsea, who  Mirror Football  understands have already made contact over a move from Crystal Palace. The 22-year-old winger, who'll represent France at this summer's Paris Olympic Games, has a £60m release clause in his contract but it's far from simple for both Chelsea and United.

That clause only applies to clubs in the Champions League, which the Blues and Red Devils both missed out on last season. A bidding war could be sparked between the two clubs, putting even more pressure on United to drum up funds by selling high-profile players.

Names don't come much bigger than Bruno Fernandes, who Barcelona and Bayern Munich are said to be interested in signing. Keen to know if he's part of United's future plans, Fernandes, who turns 30 in September, wants a lucrative new contract which would put him in the same wage bracket as high earners Casemiro, Sancho and Marcus Rashford - who's also been tipped for a surprise exit but is more than likely to stay.

It's expected that Old Trafford chiefs will offer the Portuguese a new deal, having been handed the captaincy by Ten Hag a year ago. Finally, despite Hojlund being untouchable when it comes to the market, United are keen to provide the 21-year-old with competition for the starting striker role.

Mirror Football  exclusively revealed earlier this month that the Red Devils are looking at signing Matheus Cunha from Wolves, who have financial concerns of their own to address and could be forced into selling. Cunha, 25, is currently valued at £60m and United would be willing to double the Brazilian's £60,000-a-week pay.

A second striker or attacking midfielder throughout most of his career, Cunha is able to function in various attacking roles, so he'd give Ten Hag greater tactical versatility. The Red Devils want strength in depth after an injury-ravaged campaign and those four signings would go a long way in providing just that.

What's important to note is that Ratcliffe wants to usher in a new transfer policy at Old Trafford, one focussed on signing more rough diamonds with high potential and huge resale value - like the aforementioned quartet - as opposed to readymade, declining stars like the £70m addition of Casemiro in 2022.

Newly-appointed technical director Jason Wilcox is set to have a significant influence on transfers, with Ten Hag's role in recruitment reduced. Wilcox will be supported by INEOS bigwig Sir Dave Brailsford as well as deputy football director Andy O'Boyle and transfer chief Matt Hargreaves.

headline: Man Utd begin work on £50m refurb project with world-class facility promised
body: Sir Jim Ratcliffe confirms plans to transform Carrington training ground as top architects hired to oversee work that will begin next week and last up to a year
Manchester United will next week begin work on a £50m project that will see its Carrington training ground transformed into a “world-class facility.”
The club have confirmed that the architect firm led by Manchester-born Lord Norman Foster has been hired to oversee the renovations, which marks a major step forward under new part-owners INEOS.

Sir Jim Ratcliffe’s corporation, which purchased a quarter of the club last December and now oversees all footballing matters, has been clear that they intend to invest heavily in improving the club’s infrastructure after several rivals have stolen a march in recent years.

The work is expected to last across the entire 2024/25 season and United said: “Temporary adaptations will be made… to ensure players and staff from all our teams can continue to operate successfully next season.”
United plan to revamp the gym, medical, nutrition and recovery areas and there is “a design emphasis on creating more space for collaboration and innovation among players and staff.”

After confirming the plans for Carrington, Ratcliffe said: “We want to create a world-class environment for our teams to win. When we conducted a thorough review of the Carrington training facilities and met with our men’s first-team players, it was clear the standards had fallen below some of our peers. This project will ensure Manchester United's training ground is once more renovated to the highest standards.”

Last summer United opened a separate building at Carrington for its academy and women’s teams after a £10m investment. Lord Foster, whose firm oversaw the transformation of Wembley among other sporting projects, said: “We are delighted to lead the renewal of Manchester United's training facility in Carrington.
“Our aim is to modernise and revitalise the building as a catalyst for future footballing success, creating spaces that inspire a culture of collaboration, unity and belonging.

“As a proud Mancunian, it is a particular honour for me to see Foster + Partners given this responsibility and we will ensure that our design captures the spirit of industry, grit and ambition that exemplifies both Manchester and Manchester United.”

United are also eager to move ahead with plans for Old Trafford with Ratcliffe keen to make it the “Wembley of the North” but no decision has been made over how to renovate the existing structure with previous reports suggesting that building a new stadium on adjacent land was being considered.
The club was widely criticised last season because of the ageing stadium’s leaking roof - in particular after a storm during the Premier League defeat to Arsenal.

headline: Zlatan Ibrahimovic endorses £34m Man Utd target as three-man shortlist emerges
body: Both Manchester United and AC Milan are interested in signing Bologna forward Joshua Zirkzee and Zlatan Ibrahimovic has hailed the "great season" the 23-year-old enjoyed
Former Manchester United striker Zlatan Ibrahimovic has hailed the in-demand Joshua Zirkzee.

Zirkzee has impressed since joining Serie A side Bologna from Bayern Munich in 2022, with the Dutchman making 23 goal contributions in 58 appearances across all competitions. The 23-year-old has been linked with several clubs this summer, including United and AC Milan.

Zirkzee is said to be on a three-man shortlist of strikers United are looking at following the departure of Anthony Martial, with Brentford's Ivan Toney and Lille's Jonathan David also being considered.

Milan are also interested in signing Zirkzee and Ibrahimovic, who now works as a senior advisor to the club's owners, recently addressed the links. "Last year Milan made a great transfer market, we needed to lay the foundations," Ibrahimovic told reporters.
"This market will focus above all on details. After [Olivier] Giroud's departure, we need a new number 9. [Luka] Jovic is there, but we are looking for a new striker.
"Zirkzee is a strong player, he comes from a great season. He comes from the Netherlands, whether he is another Ibra or not… there is a big difference between reality and what is said and written.

"When we talk about negotiations, we think that a club are under pressure and are trying to exploit the situation. It's a negotiation, it goes back and forth, it's not a charity. It has to go well for the club. We're smart and intelligent, it's not rock and roll."

Zirkzee is rumoured to have a £34million release clause in his current contract, but the forward is currently focusing on Euro 2024 after he was called up to the Netherlands squad alongside Chelsea's Ian Maatsen.

The pair are injury replacements for Frenkie de Jong and Teun Koopmeiners, who have both been ruled out of the tournament. De Jong has failed to recover from an ankle injury he picked up in March, while Koopmeiners suffered a groin injury ahead of the Netherlands' warm-up match against Iceland.

headline: Man Utd accused of disrespecting Erik ten Hag as details of harsh internal meeting emerge
body: Manchester United's flirtations with other head coaches while waiting to decide whether to stick with Erik ten Hag has been described as madness by a former Old Trafford favourite
The manner of Manchester United's internal review has been branded as disrespectful towards head coach Erik ten Hag, a former Old Trafford star has claimed.
And Paul Ince said it was “madness” for the club to hold talks with potential replacements, including ex-Chelsea boss Thomas Tuchel, while Ten Hag’s future appeared unclear.
It was confirmed on Tuesday night that United are set to stick with Ten Hag after winning the FA Cup and talks are underway over a new contract.
But Ince thinks the way United allowed a will-they-won’t-they sack Ten Hag narrative to develop over the past three weeks does not paint an impressive picture of the new Ineos regime.
“When it comes to Manchester United's internal review, I think there's a lack of respect for Erik ten Hag, I really do. It's total madness what's going on here,” Ince said, speaking to Bet365.

“Obviously they've won the FA Cup, which is great, but look at Louis van Gaal winning the FA Cup and getting sacked the next day, they need to wash away from the idea that they need to keep him because he won that.
“The Premier League, that's your bread and butter. The 38 games in the Premier League and where do you finish? They finished eighth, which is nowhere near good enough.
“It hasn't been good enough for a long, long time. Maybe they feel that with Jason Wilcox coming in and Dan Ashworth coming in that things can improve next year.

“Now it looks to me like they're trying to look for other managers to see who are prepared to go to Manchester United, having meetings with Thomas Tuchel and Mauricio Pochettino, that is a lack of respect, it’s disrespectful for the manager at the football club.”

‌United had also been linked with Mauricio Pochettino and Roberto de Zerbi, who left Chelsea and Brighton at the end of the season. However, Ince reiterated that displayed a “lack of respect” to Ten Hag.
He added‌: “I'd hate to think that I'm managing a football team and my colleagues are out talking to other managers while you're sitting in the job. Surely there has to be a lack of respect.

“There has to be and I think it's so unfair on Ten Hag I really, really do. In that position you’d just want to know are you keeping me or are you not keeping me? If I'm going to go then let me go because there might be possibilities of me going somewhere else before the season starts.
“But don't kind of play this game where you are calling other managers, Pochettino or Roberto De Zerbi or whoever, before making your decision.

“If they're actually meeting managers and making it publicly known that they're meeting managers, then you have to question if they have 100 per cent faith in Ten Hag, they need to make a decision because it’s been two and a half weeks now and it shows a lack of respect.”

headline: Matheus Cunha drops huge Man Utd hint with answer to transfer question - 'If I'm lucky'
body: Wolves forward Matheus Cunha is a transfer target for Manchester United and the 25-year-old says it is a "real honour" to be linked with a potential move to Old Trafford
Wolves star Matheus Cunha has admitted it is a "real honour" to be linked with Manchester United and admitted "you never know" what might happen this summer.

Mirror Football understands that United consistently tracked Cunha last season as he scored 12 Premier League goals in 32 games and the forward is high on their list of potential replacements for Anthony Martial, who left the club after his contract expired.

Cunha fits the profile of the type of player new co-owner Sir Jim Ratcliffe wants to bring to Old Trafford. And in a video that has circulated on social media, the 25-year-old can be seen discussing a potential move to United with friends.

When asked if he will be joining the Red Devils, Cunha said: "You know it's a real honour to have your name linked to Manchester United. One of the biggest clubs in the world. But I'm happy at Wolves.

"If I'm lucky, I play another good season, but the window is open, you never know." It is not the first time Cunha has spoken out about a move to Old Trafford, having told Globo Esporte, he replied: "Whenever I can, I come along [to Botafogo-PB games].

"I always want to show that (the affection) is reciprocated. Then we see that talk (Manchester United). But I’m very happy at Wolves. My focus is on resting and making the most of my time with my family. I'm very happy at Wolves. The focus now is on having better seasons and helping the club. God willing, I'll continue on this path."

Cunha joined Wolves on loan from Atletico Madrid in January 2023, before completing a permanent £44million transfer at the end of the season. And Wolves captain Max Kilman has been impressed by the way Cunha "kicked on" in his first full season at Molineux.

"He's been fabulous," Kilman said of Cunha earlier this season. "There's added pressure on our forwards because we don't have many and you could see in the celebrations just how much it meant to everyone.
"He's a really funny guy and sees the world differently! He's a really nice guy and on the pitch you can see his character. He's been phenomenal and has really kicked on this season."

headline: Erik ten Hag priority becomes clear after Man Utd stars 'mocked' manager behind his back
body: Manchester United manager Erik ten Hag will remain in charge following an end-of-season review, but the Dutchman has several issues that he will need to address
Manchester United boss Erik ten Hag was reportedly mocked behind his back by some Red Devils players last season.

Ten Hag will remain United manager following an end-of-season review led by the club's new co-owner Sir Jim Ratcliffe, with the Dutchman given a stay of execution. United are also set to hold talks with Ten Hag over a new deal, with the club wanting to change his role from manager to head coach.

And with Ten Hag now starting to plan for next season, one of his main priorities will be ensuring harmony in the dressing room. There have been several public disputes during his time at Old Trafford so far, most notably Cristiano Ronaldo's critical interview with Piers Morgan and Jadon Sancho accusing Ten Hag of lying.

According to a report from the Daily Mail, some United stars even mocked the manager behind his back by making buzzing noises. The noises were a reference to a training session early in Ten Hag's tenure when he told the squad he wanted them to buzz around the opposition 'like bees' when they were out of possession, with the 54-year-old making buzzing noises to illustrate his point.
Despite the incident, the report states that Ten Hag still 'retains the backing of most of the players'. However, it does not that 'more harmony is required in the dressing room'.

United's FA Cup win ensured the season ended on a high after the Red Devils recorded their worst-ever Premier League finish, but a defiant Ten Hag said after the game that his record of winning trophies deserves more respect.

"If they don't want me anymore I will go somewhere else to win trophies - because that's what I have always done throughout my career," he said. "When I came here I said I had come to win trophies and we have now won two.

"That isn't bad, is it? This club hasn't won many trophies over the last 10 years. INEOS have told me - but they don't have to tell me every week. I am where I want to be. When I came here, United were in a mess.

"I don't know (about the future). But this team now has an identity. Now we have ended the season on a high and we have all summer to enjoy it. The team is developing, the team is winning and the team plays to an identity but you need the players to be available and a strong squad especially when you play in England and Europe.

"We need more players because the depth in the squad is by far not good enough. Also, still, we need transfer windows to bring better players in and also players who are always available or often valuable because when the players are not robust enough, you cannot win trophies."

headline: Jim Ratcliffe has made stance clear on Jarrad Branthwaite transfer amid agreement
body: Manchester United have agreed personal terms with Everton defender Jarrad Branthwaite, but the Red Devils are yet to finalise a transfer fee with their Premier League rivals
Manchester United have struck an agreement with Jarrad Branthwaite ahead of a potential transfer - but it's unlikely they will pay over the odds for the Everton defender.

The Red Devils are expected to be busy in the transfer window with Ineos, led by Sir Jim Ratcliffe, now calling the shots. And with United confirming that manager Erik ten Hag will remain in his post earlier this week, it's expected that transfer activity at Old Trafford will now begin to ramp up.

Branthwaite, 21, has been linked with United for months after impressing for Everton in the Premier League last season. The Times now report that United have agreed personal terms with the centre-half, who narrowly missed out on a place in England's Euro 2024 squad earlier this month.

The next step is for United to agree a fee with Everton for the players services. And while the Toffees will demand a premium price for Branthwaite, United's top brass have already indicated they will not be held to ransom for the former Carlisle United man.

It was outlined last month in a report by The Mail that Ratcliffe and co value Branthwaite at around the £55million mark. More recent reports, however, have detailed that Everton will demand a sum in the region of £70m for the impressive young defender, who has made a big impact at Goodison Park after returning from a breakout loan at PSV Eindhoven.

Given Everton's financial situation, it's likely Manchester United will attempt to drive down the price of any deal for Branthwaite - particularly given that the deadline for clubs to get their finances in order to meet profit and sustainability rules for the season is June 30.

Everton were docked eight points last season for breaching the Premier League's profit and sustainability rules and Everton director of football Kevin Thelwell admitted in a letter to fans last month that players would be sold this summer. He said: "The reality is, given the regulations in place and the Club’s current financial position, we have to trade well.

"Working within such tight financial parameters makes the job extremely difficult. Whilst we want to ensure that the team is as competitive as possible, we cannot lose sight of our central objective to protect the long-term stability of the club."

Ratcliffe has been critical of Manchester United's transfer activity in the past and it's expected that the Ineos chief and his football operations team will pursue deals which represent value for money, meaning negotiations over a deal for Branthwaite could drag on.

As well as talks with Branthwaite, Manchester United are also interested in doing a deal for Lille prodigy Leny Yoro. Real Madrid are considered the favourites to land the sought-after defender, though, with the 18-year-old likely to be sold this summer after entering the final 12 months of his contract.

headline: Kobbie Mainoo wastes no time in dispelling myth about Man Utd star at Euros
body: Manchester United teenager Kobbie Mainoo is one of two representatives of his club in England's Euro 2024 squad and was able to put one particular rumour to bed
Kobbie Mainoo proved he's far taller than 5'7", despite what the internet has said about him.

Manchester United midfielder Mainoo, 19, joined England colleague Cole Palmer on the 'Lions' Den' YouTube show previewing the Three Lions' Euros campaign. He is one of just two United players in the camp, along with left-back Luke Shaw, with colleague Marcus Rashford among the high-profile absentees.
During the show, presenter Josh Denzel queried Mainoo on his height. The youngster is described as being 5'7" by certain online sources, but that didn't sync with the eye test.
Denzel spoke about the "endless hours of research" he conducted before the show. That research threw up Mainoo's alleged height, and he allowed the United star to set the record straight.
"I found something quite interesting," Denzel began. "Because when I was searching the internet, it says your height is 5'7", Kobbie, but I know you've been telling people you're six foot."
The statement prompted Palmer to ask his team-mate directly, with Mainoo doubling down on the six-foot claim. Then, after a chuckle, he asked, "Why are you laughing?".

There was only one thing for it. Denzel brought out the tape measure, asking Palmer to hold it up alongside his team-mate. Sure enough, Mainoo was 184 centimetres - a fraction above six foot - albeit with shoes on.

Earlier in the same broadcast, Palmer and Mainoo had been speaking about their inclusion in Gareth Southgate's squad. Both players were uncapped this time last season, but they forced their way into the reckoning after impressive seasons. Not that either of them saw it coming, though. "When I went to Chelsea this was the last thing I thought about," Palmer said

"I was just taking it game by game," Mainoo added. "Obviously, we [Manchester United] didn't have the best season, so I was just looking for the next game, the next game, to just try and get performances in. Then it got to the end of the season and I was in the provisional squad, and I was buzzing. It was a nice surprise."
England had mixed fortunes in their two warm-up games. They beat Bosnia and Herzegovina 3-0 at St James' Park, only to then fall to a 1-0 defeat against Iceland at Wembley.

The first of those games saw Palmer score his first senior international goal from the penalty spot. "I nearly slipped, to be fair," the Chelsea star said. "When it went in I thought I might have double-kicked it."

Gareth Southgate's team will begin their Euros campaign against Serbia on Sunday, with Denmark and Slovenia also in their group. Palmer and Mainoo both featured in the warm-up games, and the pair will be pushing for a start in the first of those matches.

headline: Jim Ratcliffe's first summer window with six Man Utd untouchables and limited transfer budget
body: Having resolved the drawn-out saga of Erik ten Hag's future and deciding to stick with him, Man Utd's new regime face another major test with their first transfer window
Now the drawn-out saga of Erik ten Hag's future has been resolved, Manchester United can begin the process of rebuilding their under-performing squad.

The window has now opened, with United's squad in need of a shake-up after the shambles of last season, which almost cost Ten Hag his job, with Sir Jim Ratcliffe and his team having decided to stick with the Dutchman, after failing to identify a suitable replacement.
Having ended last season in eighth place, their worst-ever Premier League finish, this summer is one of huge significance for United in terms of making their squad competitive once again.

Ratcliffe's newly-installed football operations team are handling recruitment, leaving Ten Hag with the sole remit of coaching the team, a change he is known to be resistant to, arguing his must be the dominant voice when it comes to transfers.

Jason Wilcox, appointed United technical director in April, is leading this summer's recruitment drive, in the absence of Dan Ashworth, who is set to take up the role of sporting director, but still on gardening leave at Newcastle.

Wilcox is being supported by Sir Dave Brailsford, who is providing ownership representation, as well as Andy O'Boyle and Matt Hargreaves, United's deputy football director and director of football negotiations respectively.

While there have been several confirmed departures, including defender Raphael Varane, striker Anthony Martial and full-backs Brandon Williams and Alvaro Fernandez, another handful could be on their way out of the club as Ratcliffe and his Ineos team tackle their first window.
Ostensibly, Ineos will listen to offers for most of the United squad, the exceptions being Andre Onana, Lisandro Martinez, Diogo Dalot, Alejandro Garnacho, Kobbie Mainoo and Rasmus Hojlund.

Even captain Bruno Fernandes, United's best and most reliable player, is available if the price is right, particularly if a Saudi Pro League club is willing to pay up to £80million for a player approaching 30, such are the financial constraints imposed by the Premier League's spending rules.

In reality, though, Fernandes is likely to be offered an improved new deal and stay, such is his importance to United, who cannot afford to undergo a complete overhaul of their entire squad in one window, with the emphasis on evolution, rather than revolution.
But United's limited budget – currently around £40m to £50m - can only be supplemented by player sales, which is why the club are willing to listen to offers for so many members of their squad.

Moreover, money made from academy players such as Marcus Rashford or Scott McTominay counts as pure profit in terms of the Premier League's profit and sustainability rules, an important consideration in the overall summer spending plan and one that could make those two more likely to be sold.
Casemiro is expected to leave for a lucrative pay day in the Saudi Pro League, while £85m flop Antony will be sold if United can recoup a decent chunk of that exorbitant outlay.

Victor Lindelof, Christian Eriksen and Donny van de Beek are expected to go, while United have already put a £40m price tag on exiled winger Jadon Sancho, while another forward who has returned after a loan spell, Mason Greenwood, is also likely to leave on a permanent basis.

In terms of incomings, United have been linked with moves for Crystal Palace duo Eberechi Eze and Michael Olise, as well as Everton defender Jarrad Branthwaite and Lille centre-back Leny Yoro. Bayer Leverkusen wing-back Jeremie Frimpomg is another target, as are Wolves midfielder Joao Gomes.

Despite so many players being on the radar and scouted, United are set to focus on strengthening in three key positions this summer – centre-back, midfield and up front, with other non-priority areas considered a bonus if players can be brought in to fill those other areas.

headline: Man Utd transfer news: Erik ten Hag dealt summer blow as manager considers 'suitable offer'
body: Manager Erik ten Hag will remain at the helm of Manchester United following an end-of-season review conducted by the club's hierarchy and the Dutchman has already laid out demands
The Erik ten Hag era is alive and kicking, with plenty of work to be done this summer.

Manchester United chose to stick with the Dutchman despite the recent torrid season, in which Ten Hag guided United to their worst-ever Premier League finish, albeit while navigating an injury crisis and still managing to mastermind a memorable 2-1 FA Cup final victory over Manchester City.
This summer, however, will need to be big for Ten Hag if he is to vindicate the faith placed in him for another season, with a number of transfer targets in mind.
Below the Mirror runs through the latest United news you need to know.
Chelsea made the first move in the battle for £60million Michael Olise in a potential blow for United's pursuit of the highly-desired 22-year-old.
As Mirror Football revealed, the Blues are desperate to beat both Manchester clubs, Arsenal and Liverpool for Olise's signing and have made contact with Crystal Palace this week.

Palace - who accept he wants to play in the Champions League - will only listen to offers between £60m-£70m to land the man who scored 10 times from just 14 league starts, assisting six times over the past season.

United are in the market this summer for a central defender, a midfielder and a striker to help Rasmus Hojlund with the goal-scoring load now that Anthony Martial has departed the club this summer after nine years.
With his veto power in tow, Ten Hag is also set to make three demands, according to The Sun.

The Dutchman will continue to not allow Jadon Sancho back into the first team unless the 24-year-old apologises. The pair fell out at the beginning of last season and Sancho ultimately moved on loan to Borussia Dortmund to reinvigorate his career.
It appears the club planned to sell their £73million signing regardless of who is in charge, but with Ten Hag remaining on board, Sancho's future looks destined to be outside Old Trafford's walls.
Meanwhile, Ten Hag's other demands include not allowing the club's hierarchy to interfere or dictate his style of play, along with the renewal of coach Benni McCarthy's contract.

Ahead of the 2024/25 season, Ten Hag is keen to bring in a new central defender, given the departure of Raphael Varane and the injury crisis endured between Lisandro Martinez, Harry Maguire, and Victor Lindelof this past season.

United used 15 different centre-back pairings this season, closing the campaign with Casemiro at the heart of defence for the final six league games. He had three separate centre-back partners in that time.
Links to numerous targets have emerged in recent weeks with Everton's Jarrad Branthwaite appearing to be the priority, but Everton's asking price may be a stumbling block.

And according to Sky Germany, United are interested in signing Matthijs de Ligt from Bayern Munch. The Dutch centre-back is expected to leave Bayern this summer and previously worked with Ten Hag at Ajax.
Vincent Kompany’s Bayern will apparently sell the 24-year-old for a “suitable offer” as they prepare to sign Stuttgart’s Hiroki Ito and also chase a deal for Bayer Leverkusen defender Jonathan Tah.
